intro: Cephaloschoenus parvus, commonly known as the small-headed sedge, is a flowering plant belonging to the family Cyperaceae. It is a herbaceous perennial that typically grows in wetland habitats, such as marshes and swamps. The plant has slender, grass-like leaves and produces small, inconspicuous flowers in clusters. Its rhizomes are often used in traditional medicine by indigenous communities. Cephaloschoenus parvus plays an important ecological role in stabilizing wetland soils and supporting local biodiversity.
